thread.title: ‘Significant heroin-trafficking ring’ broken, police say
thread.title_full: ‘Significant heroin-trafficking ring’ broken, police say - The Washington Post

author: washingtonpost blogs
title: ‘Significant heroin-trafficking ring’ broken, police say

organizations.name: virginia state police bureau of criminal investigation

text:
March 20 at 10:31 AM Follow @postmetrogirl Eleven people have been arrested and charged in what authorities are calling a “significant heroin-trafficking ring” in the D.C. region.
The suspects face charges of racketeering, drug possession and distribution, according to the Alexandria Police Department, which was involved in the investigation along with officials from the Virginia State Police’s Fairfax field office.
The arrests happened Saturday in Alexandria and in Prince William, Fairfax and Prince George’s counties, police said, after officials investigated several heroin overdoses in Alexandria.
Police with search warrants seized 10 firearms, more than 700 grams of heroin, cocaine and PCP, plus seven pounds of marijuana, vehicles and $18,000 in cash, officials said.
“With the ruthless impact heroin has had on our communities across the Commonwealth, investigations like this are vital for residents to be empowered to take back their neighborhoods from drug-trafficking organizations,” Lt. Col. Gary Settle of the Virginia State Police Bureau of Criminal Investigation said in a news release.
Those who were arrested include:
● Robert E. Hunt, 54, of Alexandria, Va.
● Dwayne Mann, 56, of Alexandria.
● Tony S. Mann, 55, of Alexandria.
● Jacqueline D. McBride, 61, of Fairfax County, Va.
● Ronald Morton, 39, of Clinton, Md.
● Tony D. Smith, 31, of Woodbridge, Va.
● Albert B. Taylor, 60, of Alexandria.
● Gregory Taylor, 43, of Fort Washington, Md.
●Anthony D. Terry, 57, of Dumfries, Va.
● Tyrone Washington, 37, of Fort Washington.
●Richard C. Williams Jr., 63, of Alexandria.
Officials from the Virginia State Police and other jurisdictions will hold a news conference Monday afternoon at the Alexandria Police Department to give further details.
